thread.title: H.S. gymnastics: Ramapo outlasts the field, grabs Bergen title - Girls Gymnastics
thread.title_full: H.S. gymnastics: Ramapo outlasts the field, grabs Bergen title - Girls Gymnastics - NorthJersey.com

author: GREG TARTAGLIA
title: H.S. gymnastics: Ramapo outlasts the field, grabs Bergen title - Girls Gymnastics
text:
RIDGEWOOD — Virtually the only thing that fell Friday night were meet records.
Ramapo captured its fifth straight team title at the Bergen County gymnastics championships, led by repeat all-around winner Emma Johnson and beam champ Samantha Marion.
Both girls scored over 38 all-around points to surpass their career bests — yet they were most impressed with all the other numbers they saw.
The Green Raiders (113.175), Ridgewood (111.375), Pascack Regional (106.65) and Holy Angels (106.175) combined to score more points than any top-four grouping in the meet’s 37-year history. Eight individuals topped 36 all-around, the magic number to advance from next month’s sectional meet to the state finals.
"Everyone’s getting better and better," Johnson said, "that’s just how the sport is going."
Going in, it seemed difficult to imagine the Ramapo senior topping what she did last year, when her gold-medal tallies included 38.25 all-around and a meet-record 9.9 on vault.
This time, her 38.7 trumped the all-around standard set by Green Raider alum Chelsea Goldschrafe (38.5 in 2007). Johnson edged Marion for the vault title, 9.85-9.8, before Marion returned the favor on beam by coming out on top, 9.55-9.5.
"This is the best meet I’ve ever seen, and I’m the luckiest girl in this gym," Ramapo coach Michelle Markowski said. "Emma had an awesome day, and Sammy had a great return [from a sore back]."
Floor was the event where competitors really pushed each other to be at their best. Three girls — Ridgewood’s Mika Tamura and Katherine Muccio and Pascack’s Melissa Riccardi — tied for fifth at 9.525, Marion (9.575) edged them for fourth, and Johnson tied Ridgewood’s Victoria Purritano for second at 9.625.
"Things like that definitely help us to be better," Johnson said, speaking for herself and her team as a whole. 
The gold medalist on floor was Holy Angels junior Alexis Driscoll, who became the first county champion in program history. She scored a personal-best 9.65 with a routine to which she recently added more degree of difficulty, including a front-handspring, front-full twist sequence.
Johnson won the uneven bars competition with a 9.725, while Purritano (9.375) collected a second silver medal in the event.
Marion (38.025), Tamura (37.225), Pascack Regional senior Jillian Dean (36.625) and Northern Highlands freshman Erika Kluge (36.175) each set a personal record in the all-around.
